Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: My phone buzzes with another message from my mother, asking how my day is going and if I’ve eaten. I know she expects a quick reply, maybe even a call, and I feel the familiar warmth and weight of her care. We talk every day, sharing everything, and I know it means the world to her. But tonight, the community study circle is meeting to discuss Quranic verses I haven’t had time to read yet. As a Muslim, I want to be prepared, to honor the Quran and contribute thoughtfully. I glance at the unread messages piling up, my mother’s name at the top, and then at the Quran on my desk, still open to yesterday’s page. My heart tugs in two directions—toward my mother’s gentle expectations and the spiritual responsibility I feel as part of my faith. I sit in silence, torn between the comfort of my family and the call to deepen my understanding of the Quran, unsure which need to answer first.
